com.codigo.aplios.toolbox.core.numeric

Class Money

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codigo.aplios.toolbox.core.numeric.Money
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Money>

    public final class Money
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Money>, java.io.Serializable
    Represent an amount of money in any currency.

    This class assumes decimal currency, without funky divisions like 1/5 and so on. Money objects are immutable. Like BigDecimal, many operations return new Money objects. In addition, most operations involving more than one Money object will throw a MismatchedCurrencyException if the currencies don't match.

    Decimal Places and Scale

    Monetary amounts can be stored in the database in various ways. Let's take the example of dollars. It may appear in the database in the following ways :
    • as 123456.78, with the usual number of decimal places associated with that currency.
    • as 123456, without any decimal places at all.
    • as 123, in units of thousands of dollars.
    • in some other unit, such as millions or billions of dollars.

    The number of decimal places or style of units is referred to as the scale by BigDecimal. This class's constructors take a BigDecimal, so you need to understand it use of the idea of scale.

    The scale can be negative. Using the above examples :

    Number Scale
    123456.78 2
    123456 0
    123 (thousands) -3

    Note that scale and rounding are two separate issues. In addition, rounding is only necessary for multiplication and division operations. It doesn't apply to addition and subtraction.

    Operations and Scale

    Operations can be performed on items having different scale. For example, these operations are valid (using an ad hoc symbolic notation): 

     10.plus(1.23) => 11.23
 10.minus(1.23) => 8.77
 10.gt(1.23) => true
 10.eq(10.00) => true
    This corresponds to typical user expectations. An important exception to this rule is that equals(Object) is sensitive to scale (while eq(Money) is not) . That is, 
       10.equals(10.00) => false

    Multiplication, Division and Extra Decimal Places

    Operations involving multiplication and division are different, since the result can have a scale which exceeds that expected for the given currency. For example 

     ($10.00).times(0.1256) => $1.256
    which has more than two decimals. In such cases, this class will always round to the expected number of decimal places for that currency. This is the simplest policy, and likely conforms to the expectations of most end users.

    This class takes either an int or a BigDecimal for its multiplication and division methods. It doesn't take float or double for those methods, since those types don't interact well with BigDecimal. Instead, the BigDecimal class must be used when the factor or divisor is a non-integer.

    The #init(CurrencyNew, RoundingMode) method must be called at least once before using the other members of this class. It establishes your desired defaults. Typically, it will be called once (and only once) upon startup.

    Various methods in this class have unusually terse names, such as lt(com.codigo.aplios.toolbox.core.numeric.Money) and gt(com.codigo.aplios.toolbox.core.numeric.Money). The intent is that such names will improve the legibility of mathematical expressions. Example : 

     if (amount.lt(hundred)) {
        cost = amount.times(price);
 }
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal aAmount,
             java.util.Currency aCurrency,
             java.math.RoundingMode aRoundingStyle)
        Full constructor.
        Parameters:
        aAmount - is required, can be positive or negative. The number of decimals in the amount cannot exceed the maximum number of decimals for the given CurrencyNew. It's possible to create a Money object in terms of 'thousands of dollars', for instance. Such an amount would have a scale of -3.
        aCurrency - is required.
        aRoundingStyle - is required, must match a rounding style used by BigDecimal.

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal aAmount)
        Constructor taking only the money amount.

        The currency and rounding style both take default values.

        Parameters:
        aAmount - is required, can be positive or negative.

      • Money

        public Money(java.math.BigDecimal aAmount,
             java.util.Currency aCurrency)
        Constructor taking the money amount and currency.

        The rounding style takes a default value.

        Parameters:
        aAmount - is required, can be positive or negative.
        aCurrency - is required.

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

      • init

        public static void init(java.util.Currency aDefaultCurrency,
                        java.math.RoundingMode aDefaultRounding)
        Set default values for currency and rounding style. Your application must call this method upon startup. This method should usually be called only once (upon startup).

        The recommended rounding style is RoundingMode.HALF_EVEN, also called banker's rounding; this rounding style introduces the least bias.

        Setting these defaults allow you to use the more terse constructors of this class, which are much more convenient.

        (In a servlet environment, each app has its own classloader. Calling this method in one app will never affect the operation of a second app running in the same servlet container. They are independent.)

      • sum

        public static Money sum(java.util.Collection<Money> aMoneys,
                        java.util.Currency aCurrencyIfEmpty)
        Sum a collection of Money objects. Currencies must match. You are encouraged to use database summary functions whenever possible, instead of this method.
        Parameters:
        aMoneys - collection of Money objects, all of the same currency. If the collection is empty, then a zero value is returned.
        aCurrencyIfEmpty - is used only when aMoneys is empty; that way, this method can return a zero amount in the desired currency.

      • eq

        public boolean eq(Money aThat)
        Equals (insensitive to scale).

        Return true only if the amounts are equal. Currencies must match. This method is not synonymous with the equals method.

      • gt

        public boolean gt(Money aThat)
        Greater than.

        Return true only if 'this' amount is greater than 'that' amount. Currencies must match.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns getAmount().getPlainString() + space + getCurrency().getSymbol().

        The return value uses the runtime's default locale, and will not always be suitable for display to an end user.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object aThat)
        Like BigDecimal.equals(java.lang.Object), this equals method is also sensitive to scale. For example, 10 is not equal to 10.00 The eq(Money) method, on the other hand, is not sensitive to scale.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
